comment.author: 69662531@N05
comment._content:
From the Commonwealth War Graves Commission website:

Name:VICKERS, ERIC LESLIE
Initials:E L
Nationality:United Kingdom
Rank:Second Lieutenant
Regiment/Service:Rifle Brigade
Unit Text:8th Bn.
Date of Death:08/01/1917
Additional information:Son of Rev. Nathanael Vickers, M.A., and Mary Vickers, of St. Simon''s Vicarage, Southsea, Hants; husband of Jean Vickers, of 96, Shrewsbury St., Old Trafford, Manchester. Enlisted in the 8th Bn. Rifle Brigade as a Private in 1914 and was Commissioned on the Field.
Casualty Type:Commonwealth War Dead
Grave/Memorial Reference:Officers, B. 3. 28.
Cemetery:ST. SEVER CEMETERY, ROUEN

comment.author: 8498561@N08
comment._content:
Served as Private S7379 with 8th Bn Rifle Brigade. Arrived in France 20th May 1915 (from Medal Record Card - Jean Vickers applied for Eric's medals on 21st March 1919, giving address as 96 Shrewsbury St., Old Trafford, Manchester).

Commemorated on the Stretford War Memorial and St Simon's Church, Portsmouth.

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
8th(Service) Battalion Rifle Brigade, 8 RB, was a K1 battalion raised in Winchester on 21st August 1914.  It formed with 41st Brigade of 14th (Light) Division, undergoing training at Aldershot and Grayshott.  8 RB landed at Boulogne in May 1915.  The battalion went into trenches in the Ypres salient and fought at Hooge, 30-31 July 1915, where the Germans used flamethrowers for the first time.  A 19 year old 2Lt of 8 RB, Sidney Clayton Woodroffe won a Victoria Cross in this battle.  In November another 8 RB soldier, 21 year old Corporal Alfred George Drake won a posthumous Victoria Cross for his gallantry in rescuing his wounded officer, Lt Henry Tryon, on 23rd November 1915 near La Brique in Belgium.  (Lt Tryon was subsequently killed in action at Flers on 15th September 1916).
8 RB were committed to the battle for Flers and Courcelette, 15-22 September 1916, the third main phase of the Battle of the Somme, which saw the first significant use of tanks by the British.  Preceded by a ferocious artillery bombardment of even greater intensity than that for 1st July, this major attack, employing 49 Mk1 tanks, sought to achieve a decisive breakthrough by 4th Army.
The assault on Flers began at 5.30am with an attack by two companies of 6 KOYLI  supported by one tank to destroy a forward strongpoint of German infantry to the East of Delville Wood.  
That achieved 14th Light Division (41st Brigade [7 and 8 KOYLI and 7 and 8 RB] 42nd Brigade and 43rd Brigade) the central of the three leading divisions of the XV Corps attack, supported by most of the tanks, then advanced taking just 3 hours to seize their first, second and third objectives of four.  The third, the devastated village of Flers, was captured by 9am on the morning of 15th September and 41st Brigade went firm there.  On 16th September the attack was resumed at 9.25am, but  the artillery bombardment was less effective and despite great cost 14th Division could make no further headway in the face of stubborn German resistance.  21st Division attempted to push around the ruined village but it too was stopped.  The remaining efforts of the Flers-Courcelette attack consolidated the newly gained front line around High Wood.  Casualties, German reinforcement, counter-attacks and heavy rains from 18th September onwards, made regaining the initial momentum impossible and the attack was formally ended on 22nd September.//

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: Serjeant E L Vickers was commissioned as a Temporary Second Lieutenant in the Rifle Brigade with effect 16th January 1916.  [London Gazette Issue 29469 Page 1582 dated 8th February 1916].//

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Vickers, Eric Leslie Grave photo War Graves Photographic Project twgpp.org/information.php?id=3276957 Confirming a Trafford connection Trafford War Dead site has a page for each of these persons named Vickers with a link to Trafford, Manchester. Sergeant Harry Vickers DCM, MM see www.cwgc.org/search/casualty_details.aspx?casualty=269857 Private Vickers, Frederick 2nd Lieut Vickers, Eric Leslie Private Vickers, Archie Leslie Private Vickers, George W.* Private Vickers, Charles Edward Eric's and George W.'s names are linked on the site - by an asterisk only. Harry, Eric Leslie and George W. Vickers are commemorated on the Stretford WWI memorial. (Stretford - includes Firswood, Gorse Hill, Old Trafford & Trafford Park.) George W. Vickers died 1915 age 33 - Husband of Rachel Goodwin (formerly Vickers), of 42, Ross St., Salford, Manchester. Sergt. Harry Vickers died 1918 age 26 - Son of Mr. and Mrs. Vickers, of Hullard St., Old Trafford, Manchester; husband of Kathleen Vickers. More research might uncover family connections. Commenting on wife's name - Jean Vickers was presumably Alice Jean Wilkinson. CWGC: VICKERS, ERIC LESLIE husband of Jean Vickers, of 96, Shrewsbury St., Old Trafford, Manchester. We read above that Eric L. VICKERS was married to Alice J.V. WILKINSON in 1916.

comment.author: 75676069@N02
comment._content: Eric Vickers was my uncle. His widow, Jean eventually moved to Nursery Avenue, Hale where she lived until she died in 1969. She never re-married. She was a very beautiful lady as I remember her with a lovely, engaging personality. She did not speak to me about Eric. I think the memories were too painful for her. I am very grateful for all the information supplied on the life of this brave man.
